message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's persistent sinus infections and recurrent diarrhea suggest a possible immunodeficiency. The abnormally low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype but normal levels of others suggest a selective IgA deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent sinus infections, recurrent diarrhea, and abnormal immunoglobulin levels suggest Selective IgA deficiency. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is characterized by abnormal white blood cells, Common variable immunodeficiency presents with low levels of multiple immunoglobulin types, and drug-induced IgA deficiency is a rare side effect of some medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest immunodeficiency, and the low level of one immunoglobulin isotype suggests Selective IgA deficiency. Chediak-Higashi syndrome usually presents with abnormal bleeding and neurological abnormalities. Common variable immunodeficiency affects multiple immunoglobulin isotypes. Drug-induced IgA deficiency is a rare condition caused by certain medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent sinus infections, recurrent diarrhea, and abnormal levels of only one immunoglobulin isotype suggest the most likely diagnosis is selective IgA deficiency. Other options have different clinical features or abnormal levels of multiple immunoglobulin isotypes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has recurrent sinus and upper respiratory infections and recurrent diarrhea throughout childhood, which suggests an immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options, the most likely diagnosis is Selective IgA deficiency, which is characterized by low levels of immunoglobulin A but normal or elevated levels of other immunoglobulin isotypes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recurrent sinus infections and diarrhea, along with a low level of one immunoglobulin isotype but normal levels of others suggest the most likely diagnosis to be selective IgA deficiency. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is associated with recurrent infections and abnormal leukocyte granules. Common variable immunodeficiency presents with decreased levels of multiple immunoglobulin isotypes. Drug-induced IgA deficiency is a rare occurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurrent sinus and upper respiratory infections, as well as recurrent diarrhea, suggest the most likely diagnosis is selective IgA deficiency. The lab results also show low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype but normal levels of others, further supporting this diagnosis. Chediak-Higashi syndrome involves defects in lysosomal trafficking, while common variable immunodeficiency typically involves decreased levels of multiple immunoglobulin isotypes. Drug-induced IgA deficiency is a rare occurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Recurrent infections suggest an immunodeficiency, and the abnormally low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype but normal levels of others suggest a selective deficiency. Among the options, only Selective IgA deficiency is a selective deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent sinus and upper respiratory infections, as well as recurrent diarrhea, suggest a possible immunodeficiency. The abnormally low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype suggest a selective deficiency, and among the options, only Selective IgA deficiency fits this description. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by recurrent infections and abnormal granules in white blood cells, while Common variable immunodeficiency involves deficiencies in multiple immunoglobulin isotypes. Drug-induced IgA deficiency is a temporary condition caused by certain medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurrent infections and low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype suggest a selective immunoglobulin A (IgA) deficiency. This is consistent with the patient's history of recurrent sinus and respiratory infections, as well as diarrhea. Chediak-Higashi syndrome and common variable immunodeficiency are rare disorders that present with more severe and varied symptoms. Drug-induced IgA deficiency is a temporary condition that occurs with certain medications, but it is not a likely explanation for this patient's symptoms.
